ORAL ANSWERS TO QUESTIONS

SOLICITOR-GENERAL'S POST
(Malayanisation)


    1. Mr Lee Kuan Yew asked the Chief Minister whether it is the intention of the Government to Malayanise the post of Solicitor-General which has become vacant.

    The Chief Minister (Mr Lim Yew Hock): The post of Solicitor-General is not one of those posts set out in Sessional Paper No. Cmd. 55 of 1956 to be malayanised immediately. It is a post to which local officers and expatriate officers who are asked to remain in service can aspire during the next five years. The Member for Tanjong Pagar is referred to the heading "Legal Service" in the Schedule of the Sessional Paper referred to, and also to the conditions under which expatriate officers are asked to remain in service, as set out in paragraph 11 of the same paper.

    Mr Lee Kuan Yew: Does the Chief Minister not agree that if we are to malayanise the job of Attorney-General in the not too distant future, it should be desirable to have a Malayan Solicitor-General now?

    The Chief Minister: Sir, the position of the Attorney-General is dependent on

Column: 1392

the constitutional talks in London early in March.

    Mr Lee Kuan Yew: Is the Chief Minister aware that the question is not the position of the Attorney-General, in the new constitution, but the colour of the skin of the holder of the post?

TRADE UNIONS
(Legislation to remove disabilities)


    2. Mr D. S. Marshall asked the Minister for Labour and Welfare whether the Government intends to introduce legislation to remove the existing disabilities of Trade Unions to participate in political activities.

    Mr Lim Yew Hock: Sir, legislation to permit trade unions to set up political funds is being drafted, and the Government intends to introduce a Bill at an early date. With regard to the affiliation of trade unions with political parties, trade union organisations are being consulted as to their views and as soon as these are received, the Government will give immediate consideration.

CRACKER FIRING INCIDENTS
(Police precautionary measures)


    3. Mr John Ede asked the Chief Secretary whether he will state the number and nature of the incidents caused by the indiscriminate firing of crackers during the Chinese New Year period, and whether he is satisfied that adequate precautions have been taken by the police in this matter.

    Mr W. A. C. Goode: Sir, incidents caused by cracker firing as reported by the departments concerned are as follows. The police received reports of only nine incidents. Three were of public brawls over cracker firing, two of burns to children, three of crackers causing damage inside buildings and one of nuisance to women in the streets. Thirty-six cases of injury from crackers were treated as out-patients at the hospital. There were two ambulance calls but one of these was probably not due to cracker injury. There were eight fire calls. In four of these, serious fires could have developed, and in the other

Column: 1393

four there was no risk. I am satisfied, Sir, that the police took such precautions as were possible to deal promptly with incidents involving danger to person or property.

    Mr John Ede: Mr Speaker, Sir, in view of the widespread public concern in this matter, will the Chief Secretary give an assurance that Government will take very careful steps to see that hooliganism does not take place during the traditional firing of crackers in future?

    Mr W. A. C. Goode: Sir, we shall certainly do all that we can to prevent the traditional firing of crackers on this festival being used as an occasion for violence and disorder by hooligans, but I am sure the hon. Member will agree with me when I say that the question of limiting nuisance over this festival must depend very largely on a sense of responsibility by members of the public, particularly parents, and on the cooperation of the public in seeing that the proprieties are observed.

DAILY DIGEST OF NON-ENGLISH PRESS


    4. Mr D. S. Marshall asked the Chief Secretary whether he will make available to the English-reading public of Singapore by public subscription the Information Services' Daily Digest of Non-English Press.

    Mr Marshall: Thanks.

MEDICAL SPECIALIST FEES


    5. Inche Ahmad Bin Ibrahim asked the Chief Secretary:

    (i) to state the total amount of professional fees earned by each of the following medical specialists: surgeons, ophthalmic surgeon, orthopaedic surgeon, radiologists, ear, nose and throat surgeon, pathologists, physicians and gynaecologists and obstetricians, whether employed by Government or by the University, for each of the years 1952, 1953, 1954, 1955 and 1956;

    (ii) what amount of the fees earned in each case is retained by the medical specialist mentioned above, and what amount is paid to the Government or to the University; and the basis of allocation of those fees.

    Mr Goode: Sir, this information is regarded as confidential since it is supplied by the officers concerned on the strict understanding that it is kept confidential. The amount of fees earned to be retained by the officer concerned is governed by Regulation 27 of the Fees (Public Officers) Regulations, 1951 which were published as Council Paper No. 26 of 1954.

    Mr Lee Kuan Yew: Is the Chief Secretary aware that there is great public concern at the fact that it is reputed that some of these specialists earn, with the use of public equipment, specialists' fees in the region of $70,000, $80.000 and $90,000 a year?

    Mr Goode: Sir, I am not aware of such public concern.

    Mr Lee Kuan Yew: If the Chief Secretary knows that these figures are true, would he not be concerned that such fees are being earned with the use of public equipment and public funds?

    Mr Goode: No, Sir. I cannot accept the implication that the specialist officers in Government employment earn fees which are out of proportion to their specialist knowledge and skill, or out of proportion to the earnings of the medical profession in private practice.

    Mr Lee Kuan Yew: Is the Chief Secretary aware that, in the case of a large

Column: 1395

number of local men who are specialists, they were trained to be specialists at enormous public expense?

    Mr Speaker: We are getting into a debate. That is not allowed. The hon. Member will have an opportunity, perhaps on the Adjournment or some other occasion, to raise the point.

CHEST PHYSICIANS AND
RADIOLOGISTS


    6. Inche Ahmad Bin Ibrahim asked the Chief Secretary whether the chest physicians and the radiologists of Tan Tock Seng Hospital and T.B. Clinic, the Medical Superintendent of Trafalgar Home, and the Medical Superintendent and Physiologist of Woodbridge Hospital, are Medical Specialists, and what is the total amount of professional fees earned by each of these Medical Specialists for each of the years 1955 and 1956.

    Mr Goode: Sir, the chest physicians and radiologists of the Tan Tock Seng Hospital, and the Medical Superintendents of the Trafalgar Home and Woodbridge Hospital are specialists. There is no physiologist at the Woodbridge Hospital. The amount of fees earned by each officer is again based on the confidential returns made.

    Mr Lee Kuan Yew: Will the Chief Secretary agree to a special committee to investigate this matter and make a report to this Assembly?

    Mr Goode: Sir, perhaps I should tell the hon. Member that we are already engaged in reviewing the present regulations governing the retention and earning of fees by these specialists. I do not want to imply, when I say that, that there is any question or any suggestion that these officers - many of whom are very distinguished members of their profession - are earning fees which are out of proportion. But there are a number of unsatisfactory features about the present regulations. One, for example, is the discrepancy between the fees earned by officers of comparable distinction in different branches of the profession, and we are now, and have been for some

Column: 1396

time, engaged in a review of these regulations with a view to revising them.

    Mr Goode: I am afraid I cannot tell the hon. Member whether the committee is aware of that.

GRANT-IN-AID REGULATIONS


    10. Mr Lim Cher Kheng asked the Minister for Education whether he is aware of the public opinions expressed on the Grant-in-Aid Regulations, 1957, and whether he proposes to make amendments to the Regulations to meet them.

    Mr Chew Swee Kee: Mr Speaker, Sir, the answer to the question is yes. I am aware of criticisms of grant-in-aid regulations from certain quarters, but so far I have received very few constructive proposals. These, for the most part, have involved only minor changes to remove possible causes of misunderstanding, and I have already promised that these changes will be made at an early date. I would add that the regulations are designed primarily to protect the interests of pupils and their parents, and to ensure that public funds are wisely and properly accounted for.

    Mr Chew Swee Kee: I have already indicated, Sir, that I will make the changes to the regulations which might cause misunderstanding, and these changes will certainly be made before April 1.

POSTING OF CHILDREN TO SCHOOLS


    11. Mr Goh Tong Liang asked the Minister for Education whether he is aware that parents who registered and expected their children to be in a certain English-language school found that their children had to go to other schools far away from their homes; and if he will state the reasons therefor.

    Mr Chew Swee Kee: Sir, I am not sure what school the Member for Bukit Panjang is referring to. There are, however, certain areas where the demand for places in schools greatly exceeds the number of places available. It has therefore been necessary to direct some of the children to schools further from their homes than I should like. I have already made a public statement expressing my regret for any inconvenience caused, and my readiness to do what I could to remove any avoidable difficulty or to alleviate the worst hardships. But the basic trouble is that in areas like Pearl's Hill, there are not nearly enough schools for all the children, and few sites on which more schools can be built. I am doing what I can to improve the situation but no quick solution is possible.

DIFFICULTIES IN ATTENDING SCHOOL


    12. Mr Goh Tong Liang asked the Minister for Education to state the number of children of both sexes who now cannot go to school at all on account of the difficulties of transport

Column: 1399

and of expense involved in having to go to schools far away from their homes.

    Mr Chew Swee Kee: Sir, I am sorry I cannot give the Member for Bukit Panjang an accurate answer to this question. However, children who could not be accommodated in schools in the densely populated urban districts were directed to suburban schools, and it is known that some 1,600 places which were there made available have not been taken up. There are several reasons for this. First, the distance is too great for the very young children concerned. Second, the parents could not afford the cost of transport. Third, they had applied for places in other schools aided or private which they had subsequently accepted, without informing the Government or the Ministry. And, fourth, they had already been posted to schools nearer their homes.

TRADE WITH INDONESIA
(Statement by the Minister for Commerce and
Industry)


    Mr J. M. Jumabhoy: Mr Speaker, Sir, hon. Members will recall my repeated assurances to this House that Government is constantly alert to the possibilities of improving our trading relations with our neighbour, Indonesia. I am happy to announce, Sir, that the Indonesian Government has now agreed to free trade channels to Indonesia for 30 per cent counter-exports originating from Singapore in part payment for produce imports from barter areas. Hitherto, such exports had to revert solely to the barter areas. Now, local merchants may supply up to two-thirds of their counter-export commitments direct to the following Indonesian main ports in the form of rice, building materials, tools, machinery, transport items and so on. The ports are Belawan, Padang, Palembang, Tanjong Priok, Semarang, Surabaya, Macassar, Bandjermassin and Pontianak. The remainder one-third of export commitments may revert half as rice and half as building materials to the usual barter areas.

    This long-pressed-for relaxation of control over destinations for 30 per cent counter-exports has been welcomed in

LIGHT DUES BILL


10.30 am.

    The Minister for Commerce and Industry (Mr J. M. Jumabhoy): Mr Speaker, Sir, I have the recommendation of His Excellency the Governor to proceed with this Bill, and I beg to move, "That the Bill be now read a Second time."

    This Bill, Sir, proposes the introduction of light dues to be paid by shipping using the port of Singapore, and the establishment of a Light Dues Fund which will be administered by a Light Dues Board. In Singapore at present, no light dues are charged and, as a result, the Colony budget has to bear the cost of the maintenance of lighthouses, flashing beacons and light buoys. It has also to meet the salaries, allowances, cost of uniforms and rations for lighthouse personnel, together with other similar items attributable to shipping lights. However, in the Federation of Malaya, Hong Kong and the British territories in Borneo, as well as in all other major ports of the world, shipping is made to pay for these services by the payment of light dues.

    The Allen Report on the Major Ports of Malaya which was published in 1950 advocated that the cost of providing these navigational aids should be charged to shipping in the form of light dues. The shipowners have indicated - though reluctantly, I must confess - that they have no objections. The scale of fees proposed in the Schedule to this Bill has been carefully assessed in relation to the services provided and the cost, so that the fees are kept down to as low a figure as possible. For the sake of comparison, Sir, I may mention that whereas in the Federation the fees are ten cents per net registered ton, our scale is only two cents per net registered ton for ships working cargo, and one cent for ships calling in for bunkers, etc. Also, in order that the dues may not throw an undue burden on ships calling very often, the collection of dues has been restricted to a maximum of ten times per year per ship. Provision has also been made for the exemption of fishing boats, small craft, Singapore Government ships and ships of war, and an annual rate has been fixed for Singapore registered ships.

    It is estimated that if light dues are introduced on the scale proposed in the

Column: 1405

Schedule to this Bill, the money to be collected and paid into the Light Dues Fund will amount to $414,000 per annum. The Fund will be devoted solely to the maintenance and improvement of light and navigational aids.

    The Light Dues Board will consist of the Master Attendant as Chairman, and six members to be appointed by me, and I propose to give adequate representation to shipping interests. Sir, I beg to move.
